key_points: Robert Bradley, a former western gunfight actor injured by a prop gun, speaks on movie set safety.
Bradley was shot in the leg with a slug from a shotgun during a staged show in Maggie Valley amusement park in 2013.
The slug was too close to Bradley's femoral artery to be safely removed.
Bradley, now an armorer for movies, emphasizes the prohibition of live ammunition on set.
He is currently working as an armorer on the set of "Silent Night in Algona" in Iowa.
Bradley offers his perspective on the "Rust" movie set shooting incident.
The "Rust" investigation is focusing on the actions of a rookie armorer and the assistant director.
He suggests that the person who handed the gun to Alec Baldwin, asserting it was not loaded, should face charges.
Bradley stresses that guns should never be pointed at anyone on set, loaded or not.
He is paying close attention to potential safety changes on movie sets following the "Rust" incident.
